unit_learning_outcomes.description: Assess the advantages and disadvantages of traditional and activity-based costing approaches and when each should be used.
Identify professional ethical issues that may arise for Chartered Accountants in business and develop appropriate strategies to deal with ethical issues that arise.
Apply appropriate decision models to short-term decisions such as outsourcing,product line development, product mix and supply chain analysis.
Evaluate financial ratios and trends used to analyse the financial performance of an organisation.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading  and preparation for the seminar.

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to MProfAcc or MProfAccgLead and (ACCG921 or ACCG8121) and (ACCG923 or ACCG8123) and (ACCG926 or ACCG8126)

assessments.description: A three (3) hour closed-book final examination will be held during the University Examination period. No calculators, dictionaries, books, or other materials or aids are permitted. The examination will cover topics covered across the entire unit.
A closed-book class test will be held during the seminar in week 7.
Students are expected to attend the weekly seminars, have completed the weekly assignment questions, and actively participate in the activities conducted during the seminars.

academic_org.value: Department of Accounting and Corporate Governance

data.description: Management accounting is about making optimal business decisions. By providing students with the technical skills to analyse an organisation’s business operations and performance, the unit focuses on the ways in which management accountants can provide insight and add stakeholder value through an organisation's business strategy. The unit covers key aspects of management accounting and applied finance, such as activity-based costing and management, strategy and strategic thinking, financial management, and pricing decisions.
